abstract.para: The topic covers enabling and disabling &selnx; via the kernel command line.

note.title: Disabling SELinux is not recommended
note.para: It is not recommended to disable &selnx;. If &selnx; is possibly causing issues to your system, switch to the permissive mode to debug your system.

topic.para: &selnx; is enabled by default in &productnameshort; &productnumber;. To disable or re-enable &selnx;, it requires a modification of the kernel command line. This can be done temporarily for one boot or permanently by modifying the bootloader configuration.

To enable &selnx; again, edit the grub configuration file to drop the selinux=0 option and ask the system to relabel during reboot. &selnx; will be re-enabled after reboot.

note.title: Relabeling your system after re-enabling SELinux
note.para: If you disable &selnx; on your system and then enable it later, make sure that you relabel your system. When &selnx; is disabled and you perform changes to your file system, the changes are not reflected in the context anymore (for example, new files do not have any context). Therefore, you need to relabel your system by using the restorecon command, using the autorelabel boot parameter, or by creating a file that will trigger relabeling on the next boot.
